description: From Middle English reden, from Old English rǣdan (“to counsel, advise, consult; interpret, read”), from Proto-West Germanic *rādan, from Proto-Germanic *rēdaną (“advise, counsel”), from Proto-Indo-European *Hreh₁dʰ- (“to arrange”).

Cognate with Scots rede, red (“to advise, counsel, decipher, read”), Saterland Frisian räide (“to advise, counsel”), West Frisian riede (“to advise, counsel”), Dutch raden (“to advise; guess, counsel, rede”), German raten (“to advise; guess”), Danish råde (“to advise”), Swedish råda (“to advise, counsel”), Persian رده‎ (rade, “to order, to arrange, class”). The development from ‘advise’ to ‘interpret, interpret letters, read’ is unique to English among Germanic languages. Compare rede.

entries.meaning: A reading or an act of reading, especially of an actor's part of a play or a piece of stored data.
examples: One newswoman here lets magazines for a penny a read.

entries.meaning: (in combination) Something to be read; a written work.
examples: His thrillers are always a gripping read.

entries.meaning: A person's interpretation or impression of something.
examples: What's your read of the current political situation?

entries.meaning: (at first especially in the black LGBT community) An instance of reading (“calling attention to someone's flaws; a taunt or insult”).
examples: [As] Corey points out, "if you and I are both black queens then we can't call each other black queens because that's not a read. That's a [fact]."

entries.meaning: (biochemistry) The identification of a specific sequence of genes in a genome or bases in a nucleic acid string

verbs.description: read (third-person singular simple present reads, present participle reading, simple past read, past participle read or (archaic, dialectal) readen)

entries.meaning: (transitive or intransitive) To look at and interpret letters or other information that is written.
examples: Have you read this book?
He doesn’t like to read.

entries.meaning: (transitive or intransitive) To speak aloud words or other information that is written. (often construed with a to phrase or an indirect object)
examples: He read us a passage from his new book.
All right, class, who wants to read next?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To read work(s) written by (a named author).
examples: At the moment I'm reading Milton.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To interpret, or infer a meaning, significance, thought, intention, etc., from.
examples: She read my mind and promptly rose to get me a glass of water.
I can read his feelings in his face.

entries.meaning: To consist of certain text.
examples: On the door hung a sign that reads "No admittance".
The passage reads differently in the earlier manuscripts.

entries.meaning: (ergative) Of text, etc., to be interpreted or read in a particular way.
examples: Arabic reads right to left.
That sentence reads strangely.

entries.meaning: (transitive, frequently humorous) To substitute (a corrected piece of text in place of an erroneous one); used to introduce an emendation of a text.
examples: Synonym: sic pro

entries.meaning: (informal, usually ironic) Used after a euphemism to introduce the intended, more blunt meaning of a term.
(transitive, telecommunications) To be able to hear what another person is saying over a radio connection.
examples: Synonyms: copy, hear, receive
Do you read me?

entries.meaning: (transitive, rail transport) To observe and comprehend (a displayed signal).
examples: A repeater signal may be used where the track geometry makes the main signal difficult to read from a distance.

entries.meaning: (transitive, Commonwealth, except Scotland) To make a special study of, as by perusing textbooks.
examples: I am reading theology at university.
Synonyms: learn, study

entries.meaning: (computing, transitive) To fetch data from (a storage medium, etc.).
examples: to read a hard disk
to read a port
to read the keyboard

entries.meaning: (transitive, LGBT) To recognise (someone) as being transgender.
examples: Synonym: clock
Antonym: pass
Every time I go outside, I worry that someone will read me.

entries.meaning: (at first especially in the black LGBT community) To call attention to the flaws of (someone) in either a playful, a taunting, or an insulting way.
examples: Snapping, we are told, comes from reading, or exposing hidden flaws in a person's life, and out of reading comes shade  […]

entries.meaning: (go) To imagine sequences of potential moves and responses without actually placing stones.
(obsolete) To think, believe; to consider (that).
(obsolete) To advise; to counsel. See rede.
(obsolete) To tell; to declare; to recite.

description: From Middle English redde (simple past), red, rad (past participle), from Old English rǣdde (simple past), (ġe)rǣded (past participle), conjugations of rǣdan (“to read”); see above.

entries.meaning: simple past tense
past participle
